content.description:
Very high 1st bolt (~20 feet), but secure 5.8 to get there (either straight up, or traversing in from the corner). Hard crux just after the 3rd bolt with bad sidepulls. Easier climbing up through some small roofs to the anchors.

A bonus letter (11c) if you continue up for another 8 bolts and 20 m. Multiple roof pulls onto slabs; generally cruiser and restful. Lower twice unless you have an 80 m rope. 


Very obvious climb directly next to the trail with a high 1st bolt.
bolts

Climb "Rubber Lover" to the chains, throw an extendo on, clip on a loose bolt over the roof and boulder up. Climb sequence after sequence that is not the crux until you hit the chains. At that point, you should know that one of the many under-cling/side-pull sequences was the crux. 

Wave at the old dude taking a picture of you with his iPad and lower off (a 70 gets you back to the dirt).

Consider stick clipping the first bolt on "Rubber Lover"



Left-most arete is "Chocolate Bunnies", the corner to the right is "Standing Ovation" (trad), and this is the bolt line just right of the "Standing Ovation" corner/arete. Starts up a dark streak. 

14 bolts, rap rings. Bring an extended draw for the first anchor, or back clean it after clipping up.

A vicious and bouldery little route. Gently overhanging, make a couple thin moves up to a high first bolt (stick clip?) and make a big move to stick the thank-god jug. Next pull a small traverse out left on small underclings, and launch into a series of cruxy sequences between horizontal cracks/edges. Two very tough clips in a row, one off of a sloping sidepull out left and the other following a stout crux with terrible and hard to see feet, guard a much easier (5.9ish) run to the top on lower angle terrain.  
  
 Totally different in style than many of the other nearby routes.

starts in the small alcove just before the climbers' trail heads up to the Outhouse wall classics.
5 bolts to chains. Stick clip recommended for the first bolt as the opening moves aren't trivial and a fall would land you in talus.

Four very bouldery cruxes spread out over 32 meters of climbing and separated by decent rests. The cruxes will completely drain you, but the climbing in between is fun and sustained while still offering good rests.



Two routes to the right of the "Standing Ovation" corner.

14 bolts.

An absolute must-do and worth bringing your rack out for. Stem and jam your way up an almost 30 meter corner capped by a roof, which you surpass by stepping right around it and up another few meters along a great crack to the chains.

Takes great gear the entire way and features a midway anchor around the 12 meter mark so you can lower off twice with a 60m rope.

Note as of June 2020 a loose flake at the crux sequence was pulled off, revealing a massive hold where otherwise you would have had to commit to moves that gave the route its grade. The climbing is still sustained and committing in the upper section, but with a significantly easier crux now likely making the whole route a soft 5.10b

The obvious and long corner capped by a large roof on the far left of Trailside, just as you start up the boulders towards Wicked Gravity.
Standard rack, doubles in finger sizes will help if you want to sew up the easier climbing in the first half.

Trailside as the same suggests is next to the tourist trail, so expect to have numerous onlookers as you climb.  The majority of the climbs are steep and fingery, with only a few crack climbs thrown in for good measure.
